docs.snippet: To the Editor:   In "High Noon at Uruguay Gulch" (Editorial Notebook, Dec. 13), Karl E. Meyer defends French foot-dragging on the demands in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concerning United States access to Europe's audiovisual market and...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In "High Noon at Uruguay Gulch" (Editorial Notebook, Dec. 13), Karl E. Meyer defends French foot-dragging on the demands in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concerning United States access to Europe's audiovisual market and France's insistence on a cultural exception. The question has, at any rate, now been deferred (front page, Dec. 15).

headline.main: Free Trade at the Movies Puts U.S. in New Role

docs.snippet: The North American Free Trade Agreement takes effect on Jan. 1, and that event is being seen in many Latin American countries as a first step toward the day when the pact expands south from Mexico, creating a free-trade hemisphere.   Overshadowed by...
docs.lead_paragraph: The North American Free Trade Agreement takes effect on Jan. 1, and that event is being seen in many Latin American countries as a first step toward the day when the pact expands south from Mexico, creating a free-trade hemisphere. Overshadowed by the debate in the United States over job gains and losses from the North American accord, the economies of Latin America, a region long gripped by protectionism, have experienced a free-trade transformation of their own.

headline.main: With a View of One Hemisphere, Latin America Is Freeing Its Own Trade

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   Contrary to "Look at What Rice for Japan Will Cost Us" (letter, Dec. 19) by Prof. Thomas Koelble, California rice grows principally in northern California with a small amount in central California, and none in southern California. No...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contrary to "Look at What Rice for Japan Will Cost Us" (letter, Dec. 19) by Prof. Thomas Koelble, California rice grows principally in northern California with a small amount in central California, and none in southern California. No water from the Colorado River is diverted to central or northern California. Furthermore, diversion of Colorado River water, while not used for rice growing, is neither an economic disaster nor environmentally destructive.

headline.main: Why Blame California For Rice Subsidies?
